title: Moon Rocks Show a Big Crash Changed the Moon Inside
summary: Scientists studied rocks from the Moon brought back by China's Chang'e-6 mission. These rocks came from a huge crater called the South Pole-Aitken Basin, which was made by a giant asteroid hitting the Moon long ago. The rocks have a special chemical called potassium that is heavier than in other Moon rocks. This tells us that the big crash was so hot it made potassium evaporate and change. This event affected the Moon's inside, making less lava flow on the far side of the Moon. The study helps us understand how big impacts can change planets and moons in our solar system.

questions.correct_answer: It shows how impacts change planets

background_read: The Moon is Earth's natural satellite and has many craters from asteroid impacts. Scientists study Moon rocks to learn about its history. China's Chang'e-6 mission collected samples from a big crater to understand how impacts affect the Moon's interior. This helps us know more about other planets too.
Article_Structure: WHO: Scientists led by Prof. Hengci Tian from China
WHAT: Studied Moon rocks to see how a giant asteroid impact changed the Moon inside
WHERE: From the South Pole-Aitken Basin on the Moon
WHY: To understand how big crashes shape planets and moons

perspectives.description: The study reveals new information about the Moon's history through chemical analysis.
